headline: September was a bad month for stocks, and October might be rocky too: CNBC After Hours
summary: CNBC.com's MacKenzie Sigalos brings you the day's top business news headlines. After an ugly month for stocks in September, CNBC's Bob Pisani breaks down what investors should expect in October, and identifies hurdles that lie ahead, like the presidential election and the rising Covid-19 case count.

headline: Google contractors allege company prevents them from whistleblowing, writing Silicon Valley novels
summary: Google contractors claim they're forced to sign non-disclosure agreements that would prevent them from telling their parents how much money they make or writing a novel about Silicon Valley.

headline: Amazon says more than 19,000 workers got Covid-19
summary: The company said it has counted 19,816 confirmed or presumed Covid-19 cases across its front-line employees in the U.S.

headline: Twilio shares rise as it forecasts more quarterly revenue than expected
summary: Twilio stock has benefited from the rush to cloud during the coronavirus pandemic this year.

summary: The trading community is actively debating the effect of more fiscal stimulus on the economy and on the markets, but they sometimes seem to be talking about two different types of stimulus.

headline: Ron Howard: The movie theater industry is 'not going away'
summary: The future of the movie theater industry may seem bleak in the U.S., as audiences are slow to return to cinemas and blockbuster features get postponed into 2021, but director Ron Howard doesn't think this 100-year-old business is going away.

headline: Sports agent Drew Rosenhaus: 'I am very worried' about NFL season after Titans coronavirus cases
summary: "This has got to be a huge wakeup call for the NFL," sports agent Drew Rosenhaus told CNBC. "This could happen to any team, any week."
